text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob. Each one came with those of his house:
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Issachar, Zebulun, Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were seventy people in Jacob’s family. But Joseph was already in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph and all his brothers died and all their families of that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the sons of Israel had many children, and the people became many in number. There were so many that the land was filled with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a new king came into power over Egypt. He did not know Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his people, “See, the people of Israel are too many and too powerful for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us be wise in how we act towards them, or they will become more in number. If there is a war, they might join with those who hate us. They might fight against us and then leave the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they put men in power over them to make them work hard. And they built the store-cities Pithom and Raamses for Pharaoh the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the more the Egyptians made them suffer, the more they became until they spread throughout the land. So the Egyptians were afraid of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians made the people of Israel work very hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made their lives bitter with hard work building with stones and with all kinds of work in the field. They made them work very hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew nurses. The name of one was Shiphrah. The name of the other was Puah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “When you are helping the Hebrew women to give birth, and see the baby before the mother does, if it is a son, kill him. But if it is a daughter, let her live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the nurses feared God. They did not do what the king of Egypt told them. They let the boys live.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Egypt called the nurses and said to them, “Why have you done this, and let the boys live?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The nurses answered Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women. They are strong. They give birth before the nurse comes to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God was good to the nurses. And the people became many and strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because the nurses feared God, He gave them families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh told all his people, “Throw every son who is born to the Hebrews into the Nile. But keep every daughter alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a man of the family of Levi married a daughter of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: She was going to have a baby, and she gave birth to a son. When she saw that he was beautiful, she hid him for three months.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the time came when she could hide him no longer. So she took a basket made from grass, and covered it with tar and put the child in it. And she set it in the grass by the side of the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sister stayed to watch and find out what would happen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the daughter of Pharaoh came to wash herself in the Nile. Her young women walked beside the Nile. She saw the basket in the tall grass and sent the woman who served her to get it.
speaker: Narrator

text: She opened it and saw the child. The boy was crying. She had pity on him and said, “This is one of the Hebrews’ children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, “Should I go and call a nurse from the Hebrew women to nurse the child for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Go.” So the girl went and called the child’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this child away and nurse him for me. And I will pay you.” So the woman took the child and nursed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The child grew, and she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter. And he became her son. She gave him the name Moses, saying, “Because I took him out of the water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day after Moses had grown up, he went out to his brothers and saw how hard they worked. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his people,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he looked this way and that way. He did not see anyone, so he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day he went out and saw two Hebrews fighting. He said to the man who did the wrong, “Why are you hitting your neighbor?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man said, “Who made you a ruler and a judge among us? Do you plan to kill me like you killed the Egyptian?” Then Moses was afraid. He thought, “For sure the thing I have done is known.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh heard what had happened, he tried to kill Moses. But Moses ran away from Pharaoh and stayed in the land of Midian. He sat down there by a well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the religious leader of Midian had seven daughters. They came to get water, and filled the barrels used to water their father’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shepherds came and tried to make them go away. But Moses stood up and helped them. He gave water to their flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to their father Reuel, he said, “Why have you returned so soon today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered, “An Egyptian saved us from the shepherds. He even got the water for us and gave water to the flock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his daughters, “Where is he? Why have you left the man? Ask him to have something to eat with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was willing to stay with the man, and he gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Gershom. For he said, “I have been a stranger in a strange land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after a long time, the king of Egypt died. The people of Israel were sad in their spirit because of being servants. They cried for help. And because of their hard work their cry went up to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: God heard their crying and remembered His agreement with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: God saw the people of Israel and He cared about them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses was taking care of the flock of his father-in-law Jethro, the religious leader of Midian. He led the flock to the west side of the desert, and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the Angel of the Lord showed Himself to Moses in a burning fire from inside a bush. Moses looked and saw that the bush was burning with fire, but it was not being burned up.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said, “I must step aside and see this great thing, why the bush is not being burned up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord saw him step aside to look. And God called to him from inside the bush, saying, “Moses, Moses!” Moses answered, “Here I am.”
speaker: God

text: God said, “Do not come near. Take your shoes off your feet. For the place where you are standing is holy ground.”
speaker: God

text: He said also, “I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” Then Moses hid his face. For he was afraid to look at God.
speaker: God

text: The Lord said, “I have seen the suffering of My people in Egypt. I have heard their cry because of the men who make them work. I know how they suffer.
speaker: God

text: So I have come down to save them from the power of the Egyptians. I will bring them out of that land to a good big land, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Perizzite, the Hivite and the Jebusite.
speaker: God

text: Now the cry of the people of Israel has come to Me. I have seen what power the Egyptians use to make it hard for them.
speaker: God

text: Now come, and I will send you to Pharaoh so that you may bring My people, the sons of Israel, out of Egypt.”
speaker: God

text: But Moses said to God, “Who am I to go to Pharaoh and bring the people of Israel out of Egypt?”
speaker: God

text: God said, “But I will be with you. And this will be something special for you to see to know that I have sent you: When you have brought the people out of Egypt, you will worship God at this mountain.”
speaker: God

text: Then Moses said to God, “See, I am going to the people of Israel, and I will say to them, ‘The God of your fathers has sent me to you.’ Now they might say to me, ‘What is His name?’ What should I say to them?”
speaker: God

text: And God said to Moses, “I AM WHO I AM.” And He said, “Say to the Israelites, ‘I AM has sent me to you.’”
speaker: God

text: Again He said, “Say this to the people of Israel, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you.’ This is My name forever. By this name I am to be remembered by all people for all time.
speaker: God

text: Go and gather together the leaders of Israel. Say to them, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, has shown Himself to me. And He said, “I have visited you and have seen what has been done to you in Egypt.
speaker: God

text: I promise to bring you out of the suffering of Egypt to the land of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite, to a land flowing with milk and honey.’”
speaker: God

text: They will listen to what you say. Then you and the leaders of Israel will go to the king of Egypt and say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. So now we ask you to let us travel three days to the desert to give gifts on an altar in worship to the Lord our God.’
speaker: God

text: But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go, except by a powerful hand.
speaker: God

text: So I will put out My hand and trouble Egypt with all the powerful works I will do there. After that he will let you go.
speaker: God

text: And I will give these people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians. When you go, you will not go empty handed.
speaker: God

text: But each woman will get from her neighbor and the woman who lives in her house, things made of silver and gold, and clothes that you will put on your sons and daughters. You will take the best of things from the Egyptians.”
speaker: God

text: Then Moses answered, “What if they will not believe me or listen to me? They might say, ‘The Lord has not shown Himself to you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?” Moses said, “A stick.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Throw it on the ground.” So Moses threw it on the ground, and it became a snake. And Moses ran from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses, “Put out your hand and take it by its tail.” So Moses put out his hand and caught it. And it became a stick in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “By seeing this they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has shown Himself to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Put your hand inside your coat.” So Moses put his hand inside his coat. When he took it out, his hand had a bad skin disease and was white as snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Put your hand inside your coat again.” So Moses put his hand inside his coat again. When he took it out of his coat, he saw that it had become like his other flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said, “If they will not listen to you or believe you when they are shown the first thing, they may believe when this is shown to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they might not believe even these two things or listen to what you say. So then take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground. And the water you take from the Nile will become blood on the dry ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “Lord, I am not a man of words. I have never been. Even now since You spoke to Your servant, I still am not. For I am slow in talking and it is difficult for me to speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “Who has made man’s mouth? Who makes a man not able to speak or hear? Who makes one blind or able to see? Is it not I, the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: So go now. And I will be with your mouth. I will teach you what to say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “O Lord, I ask of You, send some other person.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anger of the Lord burned against Moses. He said, “Is not Aaron the Levite your brother? I know he can speak well. Also, he is coming to meet you. And when he sees you, he will be glad in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must speak to him and put the words in his mouth. I will be with your mouth and his mouth. I will teach you what you are to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will speak to the people for you. He will be a mouth for you. And you will be as God to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will take this special stick in your hand. And you will use it to make the special things happen for the people to see.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses left and returned to Jethro his father-in-law, and said to him, “I ask of you, let me return to my brothers in Egypt to see if they are still alive.” And Jethro said to Moses, “Go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses in Midian, “Return to Egypt. For all the men who wanted to kill you are dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took his wife and sons and put them on a donkey, and he returned to the land of Egypt. Moses also took the special stick of God in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “When you return to Egypt, make sure you show Pharaoh all the works that I have placed in your power. But I will make his heart hard so that he will not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say to Pharaoh, ‘The Lord says this: “Israel is My son, My first-born.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I say to you, ‘Let My son go. Let him work for Me.’ But if you will not let him go, I will kill your son, your first-born.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord met Moses at a resting place on the way and would have put him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zipporah took a knife and cut off her son’s piece of skin and threw it at Moses’ feet. And she said, “For sure you are a husband of blood to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord let him alone. Zipporah said, “You are a husband of blood,” because of the religious act of becoming a Jew.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “Go to meet Moses in the desert.” So he went and met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord with which He had sent him. And he told him about all the special works that the Lord had told him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went and gathered together all the leaders of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron spoke all the words which the Lord had spoken to Moses. Then he did all the special works for the people to see.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people believed. When they heard that the Lord cared about the people of Israel and had seen their suffering, they bowed to the ground and worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, “The Lord, the God of Israel, says this: ‘Let My people go, that they may have a special supper to honor Me in the desert.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord, that I should obey Him and let Israel go? I do not know the Lord. And I will not let Israel go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. We ask of you, let us travel into the desert three days, to give a gift on an altar in worship to the Lord our God. Or He may send death to us by disease or by the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why do you take the people away from their work? Return to your work!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said, “See, the people of the land are now many. And you would have them stop working!”
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Pharaoh told the men who made the people work,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not give the people straw for making clay blocks any more. Let them go and gather straw for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: But have them make the same number of clay blocks as before, and no less. They are crying, ‘Let us go and give a gift in worship to our God,’ because they are lazy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let more work be given to the men so they will not have time to listen to lies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men who made the people work went out and said to the people, “This is what Pharaoh says: ‘I will not give you straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: You go and get straw for yourselves where you can find it. But you will not work any less than before.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people went out through all the land of Egypt to gather what they could use for straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men who made them work made them hurry, saying, “Finish your full day’s work as you did when there was straw.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Hebrew men who had been made to rule over the people by Pharaoh’s work-leaders were beaten. They were asked, “Why have you not made as many clay blocks yesterday or today as you made before?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Hebrew men who made the people work went to Pharaoh and cried, “Why do you act this way toward your servants?
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no straw given to your servants. Yet they still say to us, ‘Make clay blocks!’ See, your servants are being beaten. But your own people are to blame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh said, “You are lazy, very lazy. So you say, ‘Let us go and give a gift on an altar in worship to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Go now and work. You will be given no straw. Yet you must make the same number of clay blocks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Hebrew men who made the people work knew that they were in trouble because they were told, “You must make the same number of clay blocks each day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came from Pharaoh, they met Moses and Aaron who were waiting for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Moses and Aaron, “May the Lord look upon you and judge you. For you have caused us to be hated by Pharaoh and his servants. You have put a sword in their hand to kill us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses returned to the Lord and said, “O Lord, why have You hurt these people? Why did you ever send me?
speaker: Narrator

text: For since I went to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has hurt these people. You have not set Your people free at all.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh. For he will be made to let them go because of My strong hand. By My strong hand, he will make them go out of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Moses, “I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I showed Myself as God All-powerful to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. But I did not make Myself known to them by My name, the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also made My agreement with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land where they were strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have heard the crying of the people of Israel, because they are being held by the Egyptians. And I have remembered My agreement.
speaker: Narrator

text: So say to the people of Israel, ‘I am the Lord. I will take you away from the hard work and suffering in Egypt. I will take you away from being their servants. I will make you free by the strength of My arm and by the great things I will do to punish the guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will take you for My people, and I will be your God. And you will know that I am the Lord your God. I will bring you out from under the heavy loads of the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you to the land I promised to give to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. I will give it to you for your own. I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said this to the people of Israel. But they did not listen to Moses because of their broken spirit and how hard they were made to work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the people of Israel go out of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the Lord, “See, the people of Israel have not listened to me. How then will Pharaoh listen to me? I am not able to speak well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron. He told them to tell the people of Israel and Pharaoh king of Egypt that they were to bring the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the leaders of their fathers’ families. The sons of Reuben, Israel’s first-born: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi. These are the families of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman. These are the families of Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of Levi’s sons by their family groups: Gershon, Kohath and Merari. Levi lived 137 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gershon by their families: Libni and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites by their family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amram married his father’s sister Jochebed. She gave birth to his sons, Aaron and Moses. Amram lived 137 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Izhar: Korah, Nepheg and Zichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Uzziel: Mishael, Elzaphan and Sithri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron married Elisheba, the daughter of Amminadab, the sister of Nahshon. She gave birth to his sons, Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Korah: Assir, Elkanah and Abiasaph. These are the families of the Korahites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s son Eleazar married one of the daughters of Putiel. She gave birth to his son Phinehas. These are the heads of the fathers’ houses of the Levites by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the same Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their family groups.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were the ones who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt about bringing the people of Israel out of Egypt. It was the same Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day when the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord said to Moses, “I am the Lord. Tell Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I say to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the Lord, “See, I am not able to speak well. How then will Pharaoh listen to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “See, I have made you as God to Pharaoh. Your brother Aaron will be the one who speaks for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will speak all that I tell you. Your brother Aaron will tell Pharaoh to let the people of Israel leave his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will make Pharaoh’s heart hard. So I will do many powerful works for the people to see in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh will not listen to you. Then I will lay My hand on Egypt. By great acts that will punish the Egyptians, I will bring out My family groups, My people, the sons of Israel, from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I put My hand upon Egypt and bring out the people of Israel from among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron did what the Lord told them to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was eighty years old and Aaron was eighty-three years old, when they spoke to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Prove yourselves by doing a powerful work,’ then you say to Aaron, ‘Take your special stick and throw it down in front of Pharaoh so that it will become a snake.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh. They did just as the Lord had told them. Aaron threw his stick down in front of Pharaoh and his servants and it became a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called for his wise men and wonder-workers. They did the same thing using their secret ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: For each one threw down his stick and it became a snake. But Aaron’s special stick ate their sticks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Pharaoh’s heart was hard. He did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is not changed. He will not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning when he is going out to the water. Wait for him beside the Nile River. Take in your hand the special stick that became a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: And say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, sent me to you, saying, “Let My people go, so they may worship Me in the desert. But see, you have not yet listened.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord says, “By this you will know that I am the Lord. I will hit the water of the Nile with the special stick that is in my hand. And the water will be changed to blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fish that are in the Nile will die. And the Nile will have a bad smell. The Egyptians will not be able to drink water from the Nile.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Take your special stick and put your hand out over the waters of Egypt, over their rivers, their pools, and all their man-made lakes of water, so they will become blood. There will be blood through all the land of Egypt, even in pots of wood and pots of stone.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron did what the Lord had told them. Aaron raised the special stick and hit the water of the Nile in front of Pharaoh and his servants. And all the water in the Nile was turned into blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The
fish that were in the Nile died. And the Nile had a bad smell. So the Egyptians could not drink water from the Nile. The blood was through all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wonder-workers of Egypt did the same thing using their secret ways. And Pharaoh’s heart was hard. He did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh turned and went into his house, without even thinking what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the Egyptians dug around the Nile for water to drink. For they could not drink the water of the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days passed after the Lord had hit the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘The Lord says this: “Let My people go, so they may worship Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you will not let them go, I will bring trouble to your whole country with frogs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nile will be full of frogs. They will come up and go in your house and in your room and on your bed. They will come in the houses of your servants and on your people. They will come in your stoves and in your bread dough.
speaker: Narrator

text: The frogs will come up on you and your people and all your servants.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Put out your hand with your special stick over the rivers and over the pools. Make frogs come up on the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron put his hand out over the waters of Egypt. And the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wonder-workers did the same thing using their secret ways. They made frogs come up on the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron and said, “You pray to the Lord to take the frogs away from me and my people. And I will let the people go, so they may give a gift in worship to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Pharaoh, “The honor is yours to tell me when I should pray for you and your servants and your people, that the frogs may be sent away from you and your houses and stay only in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said, “Tomorrow.” And Moses said, “May it be as you say. You will know that there is no one like the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The frogs will go away from you and your houses and your servants and your people. They will stay only in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went away from Pharaoh. And Moses cried to the Lord about the frogs that He had brought against Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did as Moses said. The frogs died in and around the houses and the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people gathered them together, and the land had a bad smell.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was rest from the trouble, he made his heart hard. He did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Put out your special stick and hit the dust of the earth. It will become lice through all the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they did so. Aaron put out his hand with his stick and hit the dust of the earth. And there were lice on man and animal. All the dust of the earth became lice through all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wonder-workers tried to cause lice to come by using their secret ways. But they could not. So there were lice on man and animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the wonder-workers said to Pharaoh, “This is the finger of God.” But Pharaoh’s heart was hard. He did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning and wait for Pharaoh as he goes out to the water. Say to him, ‘The Lord says this: “Let My people go, so they may worship Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you will not let My people go, I will send many flies upon you and upon your servants and upon your people and into your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies, and also the ground will be covered with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on that day I will set apart the land of Goshen where My people are living so no flies will be there. Then you may know that I, the Lord, am in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will divide My people from your people. Tomorrow you will see this happen.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord did so. And there came a great many flies flying all over inside the house of the Pharaoh and in the houses of his servants. The land was destroyed because of the many flies in all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron and said, “Go and give a gift in worship to your God here in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “It is not right to do this. For the Egyptians hate what we would give in worship to the Lord our God. If the Egyptians see us giving this gift and doing what they think is sinful, will they not throw stones at us?
speaker: Narrator

text: We must travel three days to the desert and give a gift in worship to the Lord our God, as He tells us to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh said, “I will let you go, so you may give a gift to the Lord your God. But do not go very far away. Pray for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “I am leaving you. I will pray to the Lord that the many flies may leave Pharaoh and his servants and his people tomorrow. But do not let Pharaoh lie again by not letting the people go to give a gift on an altar to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord did as Moses asked. He took the many flies away from Pharaoh and his servants and his people. Not one was left.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh made his heart hard this time also. He did not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says this: “Let My people go, so they may worship Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you will not let them go, and still hold them,
speaker: Narrator

text: the hand of the Lord will come with a very bad disease on your animals in the field: on the horses, the donkeys, the camels, the cattle and the flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord will divide the animals of Israel from the animals of Egypt. So nothing will die of all that belongs to the people of Israel.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made a time for this, saying, “Tomorrow the Lord will do this in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord did this on the next day. All the animals of Egypt died. But not one of the animals died that belonged to the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh learned that not one of the animals of Israel was dead. But the heart of Pharaoh was hard. He did not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Fill your hands with ashes from a stove. Let Moses throw them toward the sky in front of Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it will become fine dust over all the land of Egypt and will become bad sores on man and animal through all the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took ashes from a stove. Moses stood in front of Pharaoh and threw the ashes toward the sky. And it became sores on man and animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wonder-workers could not stand in front of Moses because of the sores. For the sores were on the wonder-workers and on all the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord made the heart of Pharaoh hard. He did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning and stand in front of Pharaoh and say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says this: “Let My people go, so they may worship Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this time I will send all My troubles on you and your servants and your people. So you may know that there is no one like Me in all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by now I could have put out My hand and hit you and your people with much trouble and great suffering. You would then have been destroyed from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have let you live so you could see My power and so My name may be honored through all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you still use your power against My people by not letting them go.
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time tomorrow I will send a very heavy hail such as has never been seen in Egypt from the day it began until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have your cattle and whatever you have in the field brought to a safe place. For the hail will come down upon every man and animal that is in the field and is not brought home. And they will die.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Any of the people of Egypt who feared the word of the Lord made his servants and animals run to the houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he who did not listen to the word of the Lord left his servants and animals in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Put out your hand toward the sky and hail will fall on all the land of Egypt. Hail will fall on man and animal and every plant of the field through all the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses put out his special stick toward the sky. Then the Lord sent thunder and hail. And lightning struck the ground. The Lord poured hail on the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So there was hail and lightning striking through the hail without stopping. It was very bad, worse than had ever been in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hail hit all that was in the field through all the land of Egypt, both man and animal. The hail hit every plant of the field and broke down every tree of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only in the land of Goshen where the people of Israel were, there was no hail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron. He said to them, “I have sinned this time. The Lord is right. I and my people are guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray to the Lord. For there has been enough of God’s thunder and hail. And I will let you go. You will stay here no longer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to him, “When I have gone out of the city, I will spread out my hands to the Lord. The thunder will stop. There will be no more hail. Then you may know that the earth is the Lord’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I know that you and your servants do not yet fear the Lord God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The flax and the barley were destroyed. For these plants had just begun to grow.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the other grains were not destroyed, because they grow later.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses left the city and Pharaoh. He spread out his hands to the Lord. And the thunder and the hail stopped. The rain no longer poured on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Pharaoh saw that the rain and hail and thunder had stopped, he sinned again. He and his servants made their hearts hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s heart was not changed. He did not let the people of Israel go, just as the Lord had said by Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh. For I have made his heart and the heart of his servants hard, so that I may do My powerful works among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may tell your son and your grandson how I made it very hard for the Egyptians and how I did My powerful works among them. So you may know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh. They said to him, “The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says this: ‘How long will you hold your pride before Me? Let My people go, so they may worship Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will not let My people go, tomorrow I will bring locusts into your country.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will cover the land, so no one will be able to see the ground. They will eat what is left for you after the hail. They will eat every tree of yours that grows in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will fill your houses, and the houses of your servants, and the houses of all the Egyptians. Your fathers and your grandfathers have never seen such a thing from the day they were born until this day.’” Then Moses turned and left Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s servants said to him, “How long will this man bring trouble to us? Let the men go, so they may worship the Lord their God. Do you not yet understand that Egypt is destroyed?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron were brought again to Pharaoh. He said to them, “Go and worship the Lord your God. But who will be going?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “We will go with our young and our old, our sons and our daughters, and our flocks and cattle. For we must make a special supper to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to them, “Let the Lord be with you if I ever let you go with your little ones! See, you have something bad in mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: No! You men go and worship the Lord. For that is what you want.” And Moses and Aaron were sent away from Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Put out your hand over the land of Egypt for the locusts to come upon the land of Egypt. They will eat every plant of the land, all that the hail has left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses put out his special stick over the land of Egypt. And the Lord sent an east wind on the land all that day and all that night. When it was morning, the east wind brought the locusts.
speaker: Narrator

text: The locusts came over all the land of Egypt and they stayed on the whole country of Egypt. There were very many. There had never been so many locusts. And there would never be so many again.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they covered the whole land and made it dark. They ate every plant of the land, and all the fruit of the trees that the hail had left. Nothing green was left on any tree or plant of the field through all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron in a hurry. He said, “I have sinned against the Lord your God and against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now forgive my sin only this once. Pray to the Lord your God to take this death away from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord changed the wind to a very strong west wind. It lifted the locusts and sent them into the Red Sea. Not one locust was left in all the country of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord made Pharaoh’s heart hard. He did not let the people of Israel go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Put out your hand toward the sky. And there will be darkness over the land of Egypt, a darkness people will feel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses put out his hand toward the sky. And there was darkness in all the land of Egypt for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians did not see each other. No one got up from his place for three days. But all the people of Israel had light in their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called to Moses, and said, “Go and worship the Lord. Your children may go with you also. Only let your flocks and your cattle stay.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “You must let us have gifts to give in worship and gifts for burning, so we may give them to the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So our animals will go with us also. Not a foot of an animal will be left behind. For we will take some of them to use as we worship the Lord our God. And until we are there, we do not know which ones we will use in worshiping the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord made Pharaoh’s heart hard. He was not willing to let them go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Moses, “Go away from me! Make sure that you do not see my face again! For the day you see my face again, you will die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “You are right. I will never see your face again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “I will bring trouble upon Pharaoh and upon Egypt one more time. After that he will let you go. He will not only let you go, but he will make you leave.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the people that each man should ask his neighbor and each woman ask her neighbor for things made of silver and gold.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians. And the man Moses was respected in the land of Egypt, in the eyes of Pharaoh’s servants and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “The Lord says this: ‘About midnight I will go through Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the first-born in the land of Egypt will die, from the first-born of Pharaoh who sits on his throne to the first-born of the servant girl grinding the grain, and even the first-born of the cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be loud crying in all the land of Egypt, more than has ever been heard before or will ever be heard again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not even a dog will make a sound against those of Israel, man or animal, so you may know that the Lord divides Egypt from Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: All these who are your servants will come to me and bow in front of me. They will say, ‘Go away, you and all the people who follow you.’ After that I will go.” And he went away from Pharaoh very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh will not listen to you. So I will do more powerful works in the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron did all these great works in front of Pharaoh. But the Lord made Pharaoh’s heart hard. He did not let the people of Israel leave his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This month will be the beginning of months. It will be the first month of the year to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Speak to the people of Israel when they are gathered together. Tell them that on the tenth day of this month, every man must take a lamb for those of his father’s house, a lamb for each house.
speaker: Narrator

text: If those in the house are too few to eat a lamb, let him and his nearest neighbor take the right amount for the number of people. Divide the lamb by how much each can eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your lamb must be perfect, a male lamb one year old. You may take it from the sheep or the goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep it until the fourteenth day of the same month. Then all the people of Israel are to kill it in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they must take some of the blood and put it on the wood pieces at the sides and top of the door of each house where they will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must eat the meat that same night, made ready over a fire. They will eat it with bread made without yeast and with bitter plants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat any of it if it is not cooked or if it is made ready by boiling. But cook it over a fire, its head, legs and inside parts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not save any of it until morning. Burn with fire whatever is left of it before morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Eat it with your shoes on your feet and your walking stick in your hand. And you must eat it in a hurry. It is the time the Lord will pass over.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will go through the land of Egypt on that night. And I will kill all the first-born in the land of Egypt, both man and animal. I will punish all the gods of Egypt. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the blood will mark for you the houses where you live. When I see the blood I will pass over you. And no trouble will come upon you to destroy you when I punish the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This day will be for you to remember. You must remember it by having a special supper in honor to the Lord. All of you must keep it as a law forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days you must eat bread made without yeast. On the first day you must get all the yeast out of your houses. Whoever eats anything with yeast from the first day until the seventh day will be taken away from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day you must have a holy meeting of the people, and another holy meeting on the seventh day. Do no work at all on these days, except to get ready what every person must eat. You may do only that.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have the special supper of bread without yeast. For on this same day I brought your family groups out of the land of Egypt. So all of you must remember this day as a law forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the first month, from the evening of the fourteenth day until the evening of the twenty-first day, you must eat bread made without yeast.
speaker: Narrator

text: There must be no yeast found in your houses for seven days. For whoever eats anything with yeast, that person, stranger or born in the land, will be cut off from the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat anything with yeast. You must eat bread made without yeast in all your homes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses called for all the leaders of Israel. He said to them, “Go and choose lambs for your families, and kill the Passover lamb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take a small branch and put it in the blood in the pot. Spread some of the blood on the wood pieces on the top and sides of the door. Then none of you go outside the door of his house until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will pass through to kill the Egyptians. But when He sees the blood around your door, the Lord will pass over the door. He will not let the one who destroys come into your houses to kill you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must remember this as a law for you and your children forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must remember this special time when you go to the land that the Lord has promised to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your children ask you, ‘What does this special time mean to you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: you will say, ‘It is a Passover gift to the Lord. Because He passed over the houses of the people of Israel in Egypt. He killed the Egyptians but saved our homes.’” And the people bowed to the ground and worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Israel went and did what the Lord had told Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: At midnight the Lord killed all the first-born in the land of Egypt, from the first-born of Pharaoh who sat on the throne to the first-born of the one who was held in prison, and all the first-born of the cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh got up in the night, he and his servants and all the Egyptians. And there was a loud cry in Egypt. For there was no home where there was not someone dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron at night. He said, “Get up and go away from my people, both you and the people of Israel. Go and worship the Lord, as you have said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your flocks and your cattle, as you have said, and go. And pray that good will come to me also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians were trying to make the people hurry out of the land. For they said, “We will all be dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people took their dough before yeast had been added. They tied their dough pots in their clothes on their shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel had done what Moses had said. They had asked the Egyptians for things made of silver and gold and for clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord had given the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians. So the Egyptians let them have whatever they asked for. And they took the best things of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel traveled from Rameses to Succoth. There were about 600,000 men on foot, and also the women and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a mixed group of people went with them, and very many flocks and cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the dough they had brought out of Egypt into loaves of bread without yeast. Yeast was not added to the dough because they had been sent out of Egypt and could not wait. They could not make ready any food for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel had lived in Egypt 430 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of 430 years, on that same day, all of the Lord’s people left Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was a night to be remembered for the Lord for having brought them out of the land of Egypt. This night is for the Lord, to be remembered by all the people of Israel for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “This is the Law of the Passover. No stranger may eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But every servant who is bought with money may eat of it, only after he has gone through the religious act of becoming a Jew.
speaker: Narrator

text: A stranger or paid servant may not eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be eaten in one house. You must not carry any of the meat outside the house. And you must not break a bone of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Israel must remember this.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when a stranger staying with you wants to share in this special supper to the Lord, let all his men and boys go through the religious act of becoming a Jew. Then let him come near to share in the special supper. He will be like one who is born in the land. But no person who has not gone through the religious act may eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same law is for the one who is born in the land and for the stranger who stays among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people of Israel did just as the Lord had told Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that same day the Lord brought the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Set apart to Me every first-born male. The first-born male among the people of Israel, and the first-born male animal are Mine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the people, “Remember this day in which you went out of Egypt, out of the land where you were made to stay and work. For the Lord brought you out of this place by a powerful hand. No bread made with yeast will be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: This day you are about to go out, in the month of Abib.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord will bring you to the land of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Hivite and the Jebusite, which He promised to your fathers to give you. It is a land flowing with milk and honey. There you will do this act of worship in this month.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you will eat bread without yeast. On the seventh day there will be a special supper to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bread without yeast will be eaten for seven days. Nothing made with yeast will be seen among you. No yeast will be seen among you in all your country.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say to your son on that day, ‘It is because of what the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a special mark on your hand and on your forehead to make people remember, that the Law of the Lord is to be in your mouth. For the Lord brought you out of Egypt with a powerful hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must keep this Law at the time given for it from year to year.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will bring you to the land of the Canaanite. He will give it to you as He promised you and your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you must give to the Lord the first male to be born. And all the first male animals born belong to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you may buy every first-born donkey by giving a lamb for it. But if you do not buy it, then you must break its neck. You must buy with a gift of money every first-born male among your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the time comes when your son asks you, ‘What does this mean?’ then say to him, ‘With a powerful hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt, from the land where we were servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh would not let us go, the Lord killed every first-born in the land of Egypt, both the first-born of man and of animal. So I give to the Lord every first male animal to be born. But I buy with a gift of money every first-born of my sons.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So it will be like a special mark on your hand and on your forehead. For the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a powerful hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh had let the people go, God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, even when that was nearer. For God said, “The people may change their minds when they see war, and return to Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God led the people through the desert to get to the Red Sea. The people of Israel went out of the land of Egypt ready for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the bones of Joseph with him because Joseph had made the people of Israel promise. He had said, “For sure God will keep you and you will carry my bones with you from here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they left Succoth and set up their tents at Etham, beside the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord went before them, in a pillar of cloud during the day to lead them on the way, and in a pillar of fire during the night to give them light. So they could travel day and night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pillar of cloud during the day and the pillar of fire during the night did not leave the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the people of Israel to turn around and set up their tents in front of Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea. Set up your tents in front of Baal-zephon, beside the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Pharaoh will say of the people of Israel, ‘They have lost their way. The desert has shut them in.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make Pharaoh’s heart hard. And he will try to catch them. So I will be honored through Pharaoh and his whole army. Then the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.” And they did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had left, Pharaoh and his servants changed their minds about the people. They said, “What is this we have done? We have let Israel go from working for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he made his war-wagon ready and took his people with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took 600 of the best war-wagons, and all the other war-wagons of Egypt in the care of leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made the heart of Pharaoh, king of Egypt hard. And Pharaoh went to catch the people of Israel, who were leaving without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians followed them with all the horses and war-wagons of Pharaoh, his horsemen and his army. And they came to them at their tents by the sea, beside Pi-hahiroth, in front of Baal-zephon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh came near, the people of Israel looked and saw the Egyptians coming after them. And they were filled with fear and cried out to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to Moses, “Is it because there were no graves in Egypt that you have taken us away to die in the desert? What have you done to us, in bringing us out of Egypt?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did we not tell you in Egypt, ‘Leave us alone and let us serve the Egyptians’? It would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid! Be strong, and see how the Lord will save you today. For the Egyptians you have seen today, you will never see again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will fight for you. All you have to do is keep still.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Why do you cry to me? Tell the people of Israel to keep going.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lift up your special stick and put out your hand over the sea, and divide it. Then the people of Israel will go through the sea on dry land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the Egyptians’ hearts hard, so they will go after them. And I will be honored through Pharaoh and his whole army, his war-wagons and his horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I am honored through Pharaoh, his war-wagons and his horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Angel of God, who had been going in front of the army of Israel, moved and went behind them. The cloud moved from the front of them and stood behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: It came between the army of Egypt and the army of Israel. There was the cloud and the darkness, yet it gave light at night. And the one army did not come near the other all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses put out his hand over the sea. And the Lord moved the sea all night by a strong east wind. So the waters were divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people of Israel went through the sea on dry land. The waters were like a wall to them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Egyptians followed them. All Pharaoh’s horses and war-wagons and horsemen went in the sea after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning hours, the Lord looked down on the Egyptian army through the fire and cloud. And He made the Egyptian army afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the wheels of their war-wagons come off, so it was hard for the wagons to be moved. So the Egyptians said, “Let us run away from Israel. For the Lord is fighting for them against the Egyptians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Put out your hand over the sea. And the waters will flow over the Egyptians, and over their war-wagons and their horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the morning came, the Egyptians ran into the wall of water as the sea returned to the way it was before. The Lord destroyed the Egyptians in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters returned and covered the war-wagons and the horsemen and Pharaoh’s whole army that had gone in the sea after them. Not even one of them was left.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of Israel walked on dry land through the sea. The waters were like a wall to them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord saved Israel that day from the Egyptians. And Israel saw the Egyptians dead beside the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel saw the great power which the Lord had used against the Egyptians. And the people had fear of the Lord. They believed in the Lord and in His servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the people of Israel sang this song to the Lord, saying, “I will sing to the Lord, for He is praised for His greatness. He has thrown the horse and horseman into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is my strength and song. He is the One Who saves me. He is my God and I will praise Him. He is my father’s God and I will honor Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is a fighter. The Lord is His name.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has thrown Pharaoh’s war-wagons and army into the sea. The best of Pharaoh’s leaders are under the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water covers them. They went down in the deep water like a stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, Your right hand is great in power. O Lord, Your right hand destroys those who hate You.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the greatness of Your power You destroy those who fight against You. You send Your burning anger and it burns them like straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters were lifted up by Your breath. The flowing waters stood up like a wall. The water became hard in the middle of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who hated us said, ‘I will go after them. I will catch them. I will divide the riches taken from them. My soul will have its way against them. I will take out my sword and my hand will destroy them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You, Lord, blew with Your wind and the sea covered them. They went down like iron in the powerful sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is like You among the gods, O Lord? Who is like You, great and holy, praised in fear, doing powerful works?
speaker: Narrator

text: You put out Your right hand, and the earth swallowed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have led with loving-kindness the people You have made free. You have led them in Your strength to Your holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The nations have heard of it, and they shake in fear. Pain has come upon the people of Philistia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the leaders of Edom are afraid. The leaders of Moab shake in fear. All the people of Canaan have become weak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Much fear comes upon them. They see Your strength, O Lord. They are afraid and do not move until Your people have passed by, the people You have bought and made free.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will bring them in and put them on Your own mountain. It is the place, O Lord, where You have made Your house, the holy place, which Your hands have built.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will rule forever and ever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For Pharaoh’s horses and war-wagons and horsemen went in the sea. The Lord brought the waters of the sea upon them. But the people of Israel walked on dry land through the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron’s sister Miriam, the woman who spoke for the Lord, took a timbrel in her hand. And all the women followed her, with timbrels and dancing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Miriam said to them, “Sing to the Lord, for He is praised for His greatness. He has thrown the horse and horseman into the sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses led Israel from the Red Sea. They went into the Desert of Shur. They went three days in the desert and found no water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Marah, they could not drink the water of Marah because it was bitter. So it was given the name Marah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people complained to Moses, saying, “What can we drink?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses cried to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a tree. He threw it into the water, and the water became sweet.
There the Lord made a Law for them and tested them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Listen well to the voice of the Lord your God. Do what is right in His eyes. Listen to what He tells you, and obey all His Laws. If you do this, I will put none of the diseases on you which I have put on the Egyptians. For I am the Lord Who heals you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve wells of water and seventy trees. They set up their tents there beside the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Israel left Elim, and came to the Desert of Sin, between Elim and Sinai. It was the fifteenth day of the second month after they left the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the people of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron in the desert,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “We should have died by the Lord’s hand in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the pots of meat and ate all the bread we wanted. For you have brought us out into this desert to kill all of us with hunger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “See, I will rain bread from heaven for you. The people will go out and gather a day’s share every day, so I may test them to see if they will follow My Law or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day they are to bring in twice as much as they gather each day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron said to the people of Israel, “This evening you will know that the Lord has brought you out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the morning you will see the greatness of the Lord. For He hears your complaining against the Lord. What are we, that you complain against us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “The Lord is giving you meat to eat in the evening and all the bread you want in the morning. For He hears how you complain against Him. What are we? You complain not against us, but against the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Say to all the people of Israel, ‘Come near to the Lord, for He has heard your complaining.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Aaron spoke to all the people of Israel, they looked toward the desert. And they saw in the cloud the shining-greatness of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have heard the complaining of the people of Israel. Say to them, ‘In the evening you will eat meat, and in the morning you will be filled with bread. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the evening quails came and covered the place where the people were staying. And in the early morning a little water was around the tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the water had gone, there were small white pieces all over the ground of the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of Israel saw it, they said to one another, “What is it?” For they did not know what it was. Moses said to them, “It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord has told you to do: ‘Every man gather as much of it as he can eat. Take a jar for every person that each of you has in his tent.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people did so. Some gathered much and some less.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw how much they had, he who had gathered much had no more than what was needed. And he who had gathered less had enough. Every man gathered as much as he could eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to them, “Let no one save any of it until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen to Moses. Some left part of it until morning. And worms grew in it and it became bad to eat. So Moses was angry with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Morning after morning they gathered it, every man as much as he could eat. But when the sun became hot, it would melt.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day they gathered twice as much bread, two jars for each person. When all the leaders of the people came and told Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to them, “This is what the Lord said: ‘Tomorrow is a time of rest, a holy Day of Rest to the Lord. Make ready the food you will need for today. Then put aside what is left to be kept until morning.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they put it aside until morning, as Moses told them. And it did not become bad to eat, and there were no worms in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “Eat it today. For today is a Day of Rest to the Lord. Today you will not find it in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you will gather it. But on the seventh day, the Day of Rest, there will be none.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day some of the people went out to gather it. But they found none.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “How much longer will you go against My Word and My Laws?
speaker: Narrator

text: See, the Lord has given you the Day of Rest. This is why He gives you bread for two days on the sixth day. Every man should stay home and not leave his place on the seventh day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel called it bread from heaven. It was like coriander seed, white, and tasted like bread made with honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘Let a jar of it be kept for your children and grandchildren to come, so they may see the bread that I fed you in the desert when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Take a jar full of the bread from heaven. And put it before the Lord, to be kept for all your children to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord told Moses, Aaron put it in front of the special box of the agreement to be kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel ate the bread from heaven forty years, until they came to a land where other people lived. They ate the bread from heaven until they came to the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (It took about ten jars to fill a large basket.)
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Israel left the Desert of Sin, traveling from one place to another as the Lord told them. They set up their tents at Rephidim. But there was no water for the people to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people argued with Moses, saying, “Give us water to drink.” And Moses said to them, “Why do you argue with me? Why do you test the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were thirsty there for water. They complained against Moses, saying, “Why did you bring us out of Egypt, to kill us and our children and animals with thirst?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses called to the Lord, saying, “What should I do with these people? They are almost ready to throw stones at me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Pass in front of the people and take some of the leaders of Israel with you. Take the special stick in your hand with which you hit the Nile, and go.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I will stand before you there on the rock at Horeb. When you hit the rock, water will come out of it and the people will drink.” And Moses did so, with the leaders of Israel watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called the name of the place Massah and Meribah because of the arguing of the people of Israel, and because they tested the Lord, saying, “Is the Lord among us or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amalek came and fought against Israel at Rephidim.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to Joshua, “Choose men for us. And go out and fight against Amalek. Tomorrow I will stand on the top of the hill with the special stick of God in my hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua did as Moses told him. He fought against Amalek. And Moses, Aaron and Hur went up to the top of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses held up his hand, Israel would be winning. But when he let his hand down, Amalek would win.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ hands became tired. So they took a stone and put it under him, and he sat on it. Then Aaron and Hur held up his hands, one on each side. His hands did not move until the sun went down.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua destroyed Amalek and his people with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Write this in a book, to be remembered, and tell Joshua that I will take away everything under heaven that would help you remember Amalek.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses built an altar and gave it the name The Lord is My Banner.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Because the Lord has promised to have war against Amalek through all time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law, Jethro, the religious leader of Midian, heard about all that God had done for Moses and for Israel His people. He heard about how the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law, Jethro, had taken Moses’ wife, Zipporah, after Moses had sent her away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he had taken her two sons. One was given the name Gershom, for he said, “I have been a stranger in a strange land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The other was given the name Eliezer, for he said, “The God of my father was my help. And He saved me from the sword of Pharaoh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses’ father-in-law, Jethro, came to Moses with his sons and his wife to the desert by the mountain of God where he was staying.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent the news to Moses, “I, your father-in-law, Jethro, am coming to you with your wife and her two sons with her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went to meet his father-in-law. He bowed down and kissed him. They asked each other if all was well, and went into the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told his father-in-law all the Lord had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians because of Israel. He told him about how they had suffered on the way, and how the Lord had saved them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro was glad because of all the good things the Lord had done for Israel in saving them from the hand of the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jethro said, “Honor and thanks be to the Lord, Who saved you from the hand of the Egyptians and from the hand of Pharaoh, and Who made you free from the power of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I know that the Lord is greater than all the gods. It was proven when they acted in their pride against the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses’ father-in-law, Jethro, gave a burnt gift in worship to God. And Aaron came with all the leaders of Israel to eat bread with Moses’ father-in-law before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses sat to judge the people. And the people stood around Moses from morning until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses’ father-in-law saw all he was doing for the people, he said, “What is this that you do for the people? Why do you sit alone and judge and all the people stand around you from morning until evening?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to his father-in-law, “Because the people come to me to learn God’s will.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they argue, they come to me. And I judge between a man and his neighbor. I teach them the Laws of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law said to him, “What you are doing is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and the people with you will become tired and weak. For the work is too much for you. You cannot do it alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now listen to me. I will tell you what you should do, and God be with you. You speak for the people before God. Bring the troubles to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then teach them the Laws. Make them know the way they must walk and the work they must do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, you should choose from the people able men who fear God, men of truth who hate to get things by doing wrong. Have these men rule over the people, as leaders of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties and of tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them judge the people at all times. Have all the big troubles brought to you. But have them judge the small troubles. So it will be easier for you. They will share the work with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do this and God tells you to do it, then you will be able to keep your strength. And all these people will go to their place in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses listened to his father-in-law, and did all that he had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses chose able men out of all Israel. And he made them leaders over the people, leaders of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties and of tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: They judged the people at all times. They would bring the big troubles to Moses. But they would judge every small trouble themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses let his father-in-law return to his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third month after the people of Israel left Egypt, they came to the Sinai Desert on the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had left Rephidim and had come to the Sinai Desert. There Israel set up their tents in front of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses went up to God. The Lord called to him from the mountain, saying, “Say this to the house of Jacob and tell the people of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You have seen what I did to the Egyptians, and how I carried you on eagles’ wings and brought you to Myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, if you will obey My voice and keep My agreement, you will belong to Me from among all nations. For all the earth is Mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be to Me a nation of religious leaders, a holy nation.’ These are the words you will speak to the people of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses came and called the leaders of the people. He told them all these words which the Lord had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the people answered together and said, “We will do all that the Lord has said!” Then Moses went to tell the Lord what the people had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “See, I will come to you in a thick cloud. So the people may hear when I speak with you, and may believe you forever.” Then Moses told the Lord what the people had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go to the people. Today and tomorrow set them apart to be holy. Have them wash their clothes.
speaker: Narrator
